reviewText: So, a blank page on Amazon... Is that a proper indication of something in the works, or can anyone make a page?Nevermind the summer of '69, the summer of '77 was where it was at..! Two sadly short-lived, unceremoniously pulled, network sci-fi series - the excellent 'Logan's Run', and the incredible, indellible 'Fantastic Journey'... The only reason I can imagine these got canned is that the public consciousness got so hooked on the likes of 'Star Wars' & 'The Spy Who Loved Me', that anything less than a $100,000,000 dollars in the making with no space ships or megalomaniacs didn't stand a chance... This 'phenomena' also 'did for' the wonderful 'Raise the Titanic', so it's not entirely unfounded as a theory.FJ shaped my 70's boyhood world more than any other single US series, and there were a few - The Invisible Man, The Gemini Man, The Six Million Dollar Man, The Man from Atlantis, The Incredible Hulk, Planet of the Apes, The Bionic Woman... Wonder Woman [hubba hubba] came later ;-PSuch a great premise, and bang on time with all of the Arthur C. Clarke / Eric von Daniken, theories of 'real' world mysteries. I was hooked from the very start. Even us English kids could imagine we were Ike Eissenmann, and who didn't want to be Jared Martin with a perspex tuning fork lazer?! Perhaps my strongest memories - and the strongest episodes - were 'Vortex' [the feature length pilot] and 'Atlantium' [the follow on]... such wonderful inventiveness, variation, surprise and that 70s knack of using contemporary concrete & glass to represent 'the future'. The pulsating 'Source' was ingrained in my consciousness from the moment I saw it, and the possessed 'Scott' was the trigger that caused me to seek out this show again... on a dodgy fan DVD set.This show sorely needs an official, lavish, box set release devoted to it. You only have to look at some of the 'also rans' from that era that are already available - some of them truly awful - to wonder again how FJ got passed over, and when that will be rectified. So come on NBC, somebody, please make a lot of people very happy...
Title: The Fantastic Journey

reviewText: Dear Sony - PLEASE release "THE FANTASTIC JOURNEY" on DVD!  This show is a CLASSIC with a great cast and an interesting premise - a solid sci-fi series!
summary: Please release this '70s CLASSIC on DVD!!!
Title: The Fantastic Journey

reviewText: This is very interesting otherworldly science fiction show from the 1970s,that was unfortunately cancel before its prime.There are very few episodes,but it is  a wonderful show
Title: The Fantastic Journey

reviewText: I'm one of the lucky ones - I video taped this series when it was last shown on British satellite station Bravo circa 1992; converted my vids to dvd some years ago.  But I would dearly love the powers-that-be who currently keep this gem of a series locked away in its vault to get it officially released as soon as possible.  This series had heart - and one of the best theme tunes ever written for a tv series!  I used to fancy Katie Saylor when I first saw this on tv in 1977 (my affections later transferred to Faye Grant appearing in the original V series in 1984).  Why is it that so much banal crap that passes for modern day tv series gets instant release on dvd, but series with some real imagination behind them in the days before CGI and large budgets are only remembered in the fading memories of us 40-somethings?  Message to DVD distributors: get a life, and get this series out there in the shops asap!!!!
summary: LONG OVERDUE FOR DVD RELEASE - BUT WILL PROBABLY NEVER HAPPEN
Title: The Fantastic Journey

reviewText: ALL OF US FANS ON HAMMERMANIACS FACEBOOK UK WOULD LOVE TO SEE THIS SERIES RELEASED ON DVD AT LEAST.THIS WAS ESSENTIAL TV VIEWING.PLEASE PLEASE HAVE A RELEASE ON THIS.OF COURSE THE 5 STARS IS FOR THE TV SERIES.
Title: The Fantastic Journey

reviewText: The 1970's and early 1980's was a great time in television for the science fiction genre; it seemed that one couldn't get enough of it-but dejectedly the audience did. So many science fiction television series had great potential during this period, but didn't appeal to the public eye, and thus didn't last long. We had as examples, `Planet of the Apes' 1974, The Starlost 1973, Logans Run 1977, Beyond Westworld 1980, just to name a few.So what went wrong?The simple answer is: Ratings, if the show didn't make the cut, it was cancelled.One of the shows that I felt was great was of course, `The Fantastic Journey' 1976-77.This show was when I first saw it on television was great, good characters-interesting stories; the show was easy to watch. Just recently I got the series on DVD at a Collectibles Fair-not an official DVD collection of course, but one done by the seller through Bravo. After 33 years I watched the show again and loved it, but it only lasted 10 episodes, well I guess we fans are lucky to get that many.I just can not understand it, considering today's science fiction-which isn't much-even on the imagination stakes, back then it seems the TV world was open to experimentation of the science fiction genre. But as I've already pointed out, the ratings had to be high for a show to be successful regardless of how well the series was made, and `The Fantastic Journey' was up there with the best, as each episode aired it got better, but the ratings went lower-go figure?Anyway, let's have a look at the characters and the episodes which originally aired on NBC from February 3 through June 17, 1977.The Cast:Varian (Jared Martin) - A man who is later revealed to be a 23rd-century pacifist, musician and healer. Varian explains to the travelers that, like many before them including himself, they have been caught in a space/time continuum where people from the past, present, future and from other worlds are trapped, co-existing on the island in a series of timezones. The only way home can be found in a place called "Evoland" which lies "far to the rising sun" (It was indicated in interviews of the time that Evoland was also the name of the island itself). The only way to travel between timezones is via invisible gateways which instantaneously transport individuals or groups from one zone to another.Varian generally uses a kind of crystalline 'turning fork' device named the Sonic Energizer through which he focuses his thoughts into what is described as a sonic manipulation of matter. The device, one of the most intriguing aspects of the series, is said to be completely useless in anyone else's hands, and seems capable of a huge variety of tasks from opening doors to disrupting electrical systems to large scale acts of destruction, as well as its apparently intended function as a diagnostic and healing device.Scott Jordan (Ike Eisenmann) - Scott a 13-year-old son of a famous scientist has an excellent knowledge of Earth history and events, but is still young and has a lot to learn.Dr. Fred Walters (Carl Franklin) - A young doctor fresh out from medical school has keen knowledge of medicine which sure helped a lot when his friends got into scrapes, Fred is also very loyal to his friends-even Willaway.Lianna (Katie Saylor) - Is daughter of an Atlantean father and an extraterrestrial mother who possesses greater than human physical strength (due to her being born on a higher gravity planet than Earth) and telepathic/psionic skills presumably due to her mixed heritage.Dr. Jonathan Willaway (Roddy McDowall) -  A rebel scientist from the 1960s, who has a mastery of computers, robotics, and his scientific and technical knowledge sure helped when it was needed by the group.Sil-El - Lianna's companion and pet (a cat she can communicate with telepathically), and sometimes scouts for Lianna (being an extra set of eyes and ears).This was a great group to be with and I liked them all, and it seems that they themselves worked well together also-onscreen anyway, it was such a joy sitting in front of the TV each week watching what was going to happen as the group make their way to Evoland, by going through different `Timezones' via invisible gateways that transported them to new adventures.The Episodes:1#  Vortex (Pilot) - A family disappears into the Bermuda Triangle and becomes trapped on an island where past, present and future co-exist. After meeting 23rd century healer Varian and encountering 16th century privateers, the survivors begin their quest to return to their own time. All the while, they are being observed by a mysterious man from a futuristic city in the desert.Guest Cast:Scott Brady -  Carl JohansonIan McShane -  Sir James CamdenKaren Somerville -  JillMary Ann Mobley -  RheaDon Knight - PagetMike Road - Voice of the sourceByron Chung -  GeorgeJason Evers - AtarJack Stauffer -  AndySusan Howard - EveLeif Erickson - Captain Ben WallaceGary Collins - Dar-LScott Thomas - Dr. Paul JordanLynn Borden - Enid JordanComment: This pilot was a bit disappointing as it should have had scenes of Dr. Paul Jordan, Jill and Eve in Atlantium leaving for their timezone, it would have given some strength to the pilot. Because as I watched it, I felt there was something missing, especially since Scott's father left him.Anyway the Network dropped the three main characters for whatever reason, and developed storylines around a new group with Varian as the new leader, as they travelled across the many timezones of the island to find Evoland. On their way, they encounter people from different planets and times who are also trapped on the island and who have adapted to their plight in different ways.Also of note is that the actor Desi Arnz Jr was in the pilot as a WWII pilot who was captured by the 16th century privateers but his scenes were cut out, boy would I like to see them.2#  Atlantium - With many of the original party returned to their own time, Varian, Scott and Fred find themselves caught up in the machinations of a megalomaniacal "brain in a box" called The Source, which has enslaved the inhabitants of the city of Atlantium - referred to as "The Unders" - and intends to use Scott's life force to regenerate itself.Guest Cast:Albert Stratton - ItarJason Evers - AtarGary Collins - Dar-LMary Ann Mobley - RheaMike Road - Voice of the sourceComment: Somehow I have always felt that `Vortex' and `Atlantium' were supposed to be together as one episode, especially when the closing credits on screen say "to be continued", at the end of `Vortex'; and in all honesty it should have been-if not then the editing was in my mind very bad.3#  Beyond the Mountain - The travellers are separated by a red cloud which leaves Liana as the 'guest' of Jonathan Willaway, who is the master of a community of robots, and the others trapped in a dark swamp surrounded by green skinned humanoids. However, Willaway's intentions are less than honourable and he has no intention of letting Liana leave, while Fred's medical skills prove invaluable in discovering the truth.Guest Cast:Marj Dusay - RachelJohn David Carson - CyrusBrian Patrick Clarke - DanielJoseph Della Sorte - ArenComment: This is the first episode that Roddy McDowall as Willaway appears, he's one of my favourite actors.4#  Children of the Gods - The travellers arrive in a new timezone and meet a young boy who has escaped from a community run solely by children.Guest Cast:A. Michael Baldwin - RitoAl Eisenmann - OmegaCosie Costa - DeltaStanley Clay - BetaBobby Eilbacher - SigmaMark Lambert - AlphaRichard Natoli - GammaComment: When it comes to episodes with children mainly acting in it, I never really liked them, but this wasn't too bad.5#  A Dream of Conquest - An alien dictator is planning to invade other timezones and conquer the island.Guest Cast:Morgan Paull - ArgonJohn Saxon - Consul TarantRobert Patten - LutherJohnny Doran - NikkiBobby Porter - The NeffringLenore Stevens - LaraComment: This is one of my favourite episodes, John Saxon's presence as an actor really made this episode work, his strength of character really shined.6#  An Act of Love - Varian, under the influence of a love drug, meets a woman named Gwenith from a religious community in a geologically unstable timezone. His judgment impaired, Varian decides to leave the travellers to stay and marry her. He soon discovers that the community fanatically worships a volcano god called Vatticus, who demands human sacrifices.Guest Cast:Victor Mohica - BarasEllen Weston - MaeraChristina Hart - GwenithJonathan Goldsmith - ZarosBelinda Balaski - Arla7#  Funhouse - Arriving at a strange 20th century funfair, the travellers become part of a game played by an ancient Greek sorcerer named Apollonius, who also possesses Willaway.Guest Cast:Richard Lawson BarkerMary Frann - RoxanneMel Ferrer - AppoloniusChristina Hart - GwenithComment: This is my least favourite episodes, as I've always felt it lacked a real story, plus the script was probably weak, veteran actor Mel Ferrer's talents was wasted here.8#  Turnabout - The travellers encounter a city where the women are subservient to brutish male authority. The male travellers are imprisoned after the women mutiny and imprison the men in a strange black void, and Liana appears to join their cause.Guest Cast:Julie Cobb - AdreaPaul Mantee - MorganJoan Collins - Queen HalyanaBeverly Todd ConnellComment: This is another episode I like, a good sci-fi story, and veteran actress Joan Collins adds a bit of flavour.9#  Riddles - Guided to an old house by a horsebacked messenger, the travellers - minus Liana - quest for an object that will assist their search for Evoland, and encounter illusions drawn from their deepest fears that are conjured by a strange couple.Guest Cast:Dax Xanos - The RiderWilliam O'Connell - SimkinDale Robinette - KedrynCarole Demas - KrystaLynn Borden - Scott's motherComment: Lynn Borden reprises her role as Scott's mother in this episode, she first appeared in the pilot `Vortex'.10#  "The Innocent Prey"- A prison craft from Earth's future crash lands in the timezone the travellers are resting in, releasing dangerous killers into a community which does not comprehend violence.Guest Cast:Burt Douglas - pilot RadisonCheryl Ladd - NaticaJim Poyner - RolandNicholas Hammond - TyeRichard Jaeckel - YorkLew Ayres - RayatGerald McRaney - copilot ThomasComment: This last episode is considered my best, as it had no less then four recognised actors in it: veteran actor Lew Ayres, Cheryl Ladd (Charlie's Angels), Nicholas Hammond (Spiderman) and Richard Jaeckel (Baywatch), a good strong story.Where's Katie?Katie Saylor who played Lianna did not appear in the last two episodes due to illness, so in `Riddles' in the opening scenes, Varian explains that Lianna stayed back in the episode 'Turnabout', to talk to Morgan and Halyana about the new order of government and would rejoin the group in several days. Sadly the show got cancelled before hopefully Katie Saylor would return.Final WordAll in all I would have liked the show to have gone the full 24 episodes, and if the end was nigh, (no second season) have the last episode tie up loose ends and everyone in the group return to their own timezone.Well there's nothing more to say except, " This was a great show and I hope the official DVD when it comes out, will have extras like deleted scenes, interviews with surviving cast members.Thanks to wikipedia and [...] for additional information to help with this review.
Title: The Fantastic Journey
